Applied Physics B
September 2001, Volume 73, Issue 3, pp 245-255

docTitle.titlePart:
Local fields close to the surface of nanoparticles and
aggregates of nanoparticles

front.div:
Abstract
A refined discussion of the near-field scattering of spherical nanoparticles and the electromagnetic
fields close to the particle surface is given. New results for the dependence on the distance from the
surface and the angular distribution of the scattered light in the near-field are given. It will be shown
that the radial component of the electric field leads to striking differences in the phase functions in the
near-field and the far-field. Exemplary computations are presented for Ag and Au particles with
different size. In a second part the discussion is extended to assemblies of spherical Ag and Au
nanoparticles. It will be shown that large near-fields at wavelengths commonly used in SERS
experiments are obtained for aggregates. In the near-field scattering intensity "hot spots" mark regions
between particles in the aggregate where the near-field is particularly high.
